Charles has held substantive ranks in the armed forces of a number of countries since he was made a <a href="flight%20lieutenant">flight lieutenant</a> in the <a href="Royal%20Air%20Force">Royal Air Force</a> in 1972. Charles's first honorary appointment in the armed forces was as <a href="Colonel-in-Chief">Colonel-in-Chief</a> of the <a href="Royal%20Regiment%20of%20Wales">Royal Regiment of Wales</a> in 1969; since then, the prince has also been installed as Colonel-in-Chief, Colonel, Honorary Air Commodore, <a href="Air%20Commodore-in-Chief">Air Commodore-in-Chief</a>, Deputy Colonel-in-Chief, Royal Honorary Colonel, Royal Colonel, and Honorary Commodore of at least 32 military formations throughout the Commonwealth, including the <a href="Royal%20Gurkha%20Rifles">Royal Gurkha Rifles</a>, which is the only foreign regiment in the British army. Since 2009, Charles holds the second-highest ranks in all three branches of the <a href="Canadian%20Forces">Canadian Forces</a> and, on 16 June 2012, the Queen awarded the Prince of Wales honorary five-star rank in all three branches of the <a href="British%20Armed%20Forces">British Armed Forces</a>, "to acknowledge his support in her role as Commander-in-Chief", installing him as <a href="Admiral%20of%20the%20Fleet%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">Admiral of the Fleet</a>, <a href="Field%20marshal%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Field Marshal</a> and <a href="Marshal%20of%20the%20Royal%20Air%20Force">Marshal of the Royal Air Force</a>.
He has been inducted into seven orders and received eight decorations from the Commonwealth realms, and has been the recipient of 20 different honours from foreign states, as well as nine honorary degrees from universities in the United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand.
Banners, flags, and standards.
The banners used by the prince vary depending upon location. His Personal Standard is the <a href="Royal%20Standard%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Royal Standard of the United Kingdom</a> differenced as in his arms with a label of three points Argent, and the escutcheon of the arms of the Principality of Wales in the centre. It is used outside Wales, Scotland, Cornwall, and Canada, and throughout the entire United Kingdom when the prince is acting in an official capacity associated with the UK Armed Forces.
The personal flag for use in Wales is based upon the <a href="Royal%20Badge%20of%20Wales">Royal Badge of Wales</a> (the historic arms of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Gwynedd">Kingdom of Gwynedd</a>), which consist of four quadrants, the first and fourth with a red lion on a gold field, and the second and third with a gold lion on a red field. Superimposed is an escutcheon <a href="Vert%20%28heraldry%29">Vert</a> bearing the single-arched coronet of the Prince of Wales.
In Scotland the personal banner used since 1974 is based upon three ancient Scottish titles: <a href="Duke%20of%20Rothesay">Duke of Rothesay</a> (<a href="heir%20apparent">heir apparent</a> to the <a href="King%20of%20Scots">King of Scots</a>), <a href="High%20Steward%20of%20Scotland">High Steward of Scotland</a> and <a href="Lord%20of%20the%20Isles">Lord of the Isles</a>. The flag is divided into four quadrants like the arms of the Chief of <a href="Clan%20Stewart%20of%20Appin">Clan Stewart of Appin</a>; the first and fourth quadrants comprise a gold field with a blue and silver checkered band in the centre; the second and third quadrants display a black galley on a silver field. The arms are differenced from those of Appin by the addition of an inescutcheon bearing the tressured lion rampant of Scotland; defaced by a plain label of three points Azure to indicate the heir apparent.
In Cornwall, the banner is the arms of the Duke of Cornwall: "<a href="Sable%20%28heraldry%29">Sable</a> 15 <a href="bezant">bezant</a>s Or", that is, a black field bearing 15 gold coins.
In 2011, the <a href="Canadian%20Heraldic%20Authority">Canadian Heraldic Authority</a> introduced a <a href="Royal%20standards%20of%20Canada%23Other%20members%20of%20the%20Royal%20Family">personal heraldic banner</a> for the Prince of Wales for use in Canada, consisting of the shield of the <a href="Arms%20of%20Canada">Arms of Canada</a> defaced with both a blue <a href="roundel%20%28heraldry%29">roundel</a> of the <a href="Prince%20of%20Wales%27s%20feathers">Prince of Wales's feathers</a> surrounded by a wreath of gold maple leaves, and a white label of three points.
